title: AB 575
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The state board is required to adopt basic instructional materials for kindergarten through 8th grade in various subject areas, including language arts, mathematics, science, social science, and bilingual or bicultural subjects. The state board is mandated to adopt basic instructional materials for kindergarten through 8th grade in various subject areas, including science, social science, and bilingual or bicultural subjects. Procedures are in place for the submission of instructional materials, with restrictions on resubmission of rejected materials without substantive changes. The state board mandates the adoption of instructional materials for K-8 in subjects like science and social science. Publishers must submit revisions within a specified timeframe or face a fee. Review committees, including teachers, assess the materials within six months of submission. The state board mandates the adoption of instructional materials for K-8 in subjects like science and social science. Publishers must submit revisions within a specified timeframe or face a fee. Review committees, including teachers, assess the materials within six months of submission. The rules for adoption of instructional materials must be transparent and consistently applicable regardless of format, including print, digital, and open-source materials. Criteria for reviewing and adopting instructional materials include alignment with state board curriculum framework, compliance with state guidelines, factual accuracy, and alignment with content standards. Instructional materials must align with state content standards and should not include unnecessary exposure to commercial brands unless deemed appropriate by the state board based on specific findings related to educational purpose or incidental appearance in illustrations. The state board may adopt fewer than five basic instructional materials in each subject area for each grade level if fewer than five materials are submitted. The board must provide a written explanation if materials are rejected, based on established criteria. The state board may adopt fewer than five basic instructional materials in each subject area for each grade level if fewer than five materials are submitted. If the state board finds that fewer than five materials meet the criteria or fail to meet the curriculum framework, a review will be conducted. This section does not limit the board's authority to adopt materials that are not basic instructional materials. If the state board finds that fewer than five materials meet the criteria or fail to meet the curriculum framework, a review will be conducted. This section does not limit the board's authority to adopt materials that are not basic instructional materials. The state board shall prescribe procedures to provide open and flexible materials submission system to meet the educational needs of diverse pupil populations. The state board adopts instructional materials and provides a listing with unit costs for procurement. The list remains available until a new curriculum framework is adopted. Information on adopted materials is accessible by subject and grade level, including publisher details. The state board may adopt regulations for exceptions, as determined by the board. The Superintendent will develop guidelines for implementation. Section 60227 of the Education Code defines followup adoptions and requires notice and fees for publishers participating in the process. The fee for followup adoption process reflects the department's estimated cost and efforts to keep it modest. The department requires publishers or manufacturers to declare intent and pay a fee before submitting programs for followup adoption. The fee must be paid in full before any submission is reviewed. The Legislature intends for the fee to be reasonable to allow small publishers or manufacturers to participate, and the state board may reduce the fee upon request. The state board may reduce the fee for small publishers or manufacturers participating in followup adoption. Small publisher or manufacturer defined as independently owned, not dominant, with 100 or fewer employees, and average annual gross receipts of $10 million or less. Revenue from fees is budgeted for reimbursements and review of instructional materials. If little interest, followup adoption may not be conducted. General fund revenue cannot be used for followup adoption costs. General fund revenue cannot be used for follow-up adoption costs. This section will be in effect until January 1, 2024, and will be repealed unless a later statute extends the date.
